text:
We land in Rome at 0845 and will head to Naples
Checked bag

Just wondering what time I should book my train ticket for 2 people

comments.comment_text:
You need at least one hour to exit from arrivals. So let's say you'll be out by 10am at the most. Then you walk (inside the airport) to the Leonardo Express train that brings you to Termini (Rome Centrale Station). Consider another 30 minutes from when you exit the arrivals, arrive to the Leonardo Express and buy your train ticket (you can buy it on spot at the ticket booth counter or at the ticket machine).
Trains run every half an hour so you might be waiting up to 30 min to leave. I think you might be leaving by 11 am at the latest. Ride to Termini is 30 minutes.

I would buy tickets for Naples around 12:30/1pm to be on the safe side. :)
Just get your tickets when you arrive....no stress if your flight is delayed or long queues at immigration.
I would buy a ticket when you get to station, so many things can go wrong 🌻
You need 3h between landing and train to Naples (to be safe)

text:
An Airbnb story for you to consider in the future. We were in an Airbnb in Fontane Bianche, south of Siracusa in Sicily on June 23 when it was broken into and robbed of all our cash and valuables. We went to the police station (called 112 over five times and no one answered the phone) and made a denuncia. The host of the house came to the station as well and we asked if the house had ever been broken into. He said it had, but it was years ago. He never told us that, nor were there any security measures in place; no cameras, secure locks (we had keys) or a safe in the house.

This weekend I received a message from someone who is currently staying in the house and he told me HE HAD BEEN ROBBED AS WELL! That is two robberies in less than three weeks! When asked, the host told the current guests that the house had been robbed years ago. He did not mention us nor did he tell the police about our burglary! I also don’t understand how the police can show up to an address and not have it flagged in their system that a crime had occurred in the same place at least twice.

The current guest and I are in contact and are considering how to proceed.

I am sharing our story as a warning to others. If you have been a victim of a burglary in this house, or one of the houses this company represents, please contact me.

And by the way, this house is completely booked this summer and still available for rent.

Grazie!

https://abnb.me/4P82aSrVSBb

https://www.syrakus-homes.com/index.php

comments.comment_text: Maybe it’s the owner of the house that is doing the robbing… I lived in Italy for awhile and one thing you’ll find out very quickly is that they do not work or operate the way we do here in the USA… which means you’ll get little to no help from them. The most you could do to help future tourists is write a review… both of you. I don’t see one single review that anyone was ever robbed… so that place will continue to be booked.
Did you report this to Airbnb?
What a terrible thing to have happen. One of the many reasons I will never use Airbnb.

I just read ur review on airbnb, ty for doing so. I personally have never had a bad exp at airbnb and I usually get a superhost and never leave valuables in and always use the one with security camera and smart key. especially in foreign country. really sorry for what happened to u

It’s quite disappointing. I like to stay in properties that use the key coded system. I ask for a special code, this way I know the guest before me didn’t have the same code.
We change our key codes daily at our properties and have security cameras . Our guests safety is our top priority. Unfortunately that’s not always the case.
I hope you can get pass this and enjoy the rest of your trip. 😥

Leave all your valuables on board as I will be back in five after a quick toilet stop “ He hadn’t said that the entire trip. My suspicions rose at this point, so I took everything with me. My point is…..it can happen anywhere, anytime . Hope things get resolved for you. It’s not a nice thing to experience on a holiday.

text: Please, no negatives or being insulted if you run the hotels there. Staying in Positano. Have water tours there and Amalfi Coast. Any suggestions as far as carrying passports everywhere we go? We have water resistant pouches and would take turns swimming. Just not sure if hotel safes are the way to go? Better paranoid than stuck? We welcome your experienced responses or plans of what to do in this case.

comments.comment_text: I leave my passport on the hotel safe 💥💥 AND carry a copy with me 🤷 I HAVE HAD NO ISSUES 👍 Everyone has their own ideas.......
We only carried copies of our passports on my phone. That was sufficient whenever we were asked.
You should carry passports with you all the time in Italy. I worked for years with tourists in Rome.

Heading to Italy for our 4th time in October. We’ve never brought our passports with us during our days away from hotel or Villa. Never even gave it a thought actually. We just keep in a hidden spot in room, often not even the safe as had a ring stolen from a safe once in Rio de Janiero.
The law says, Dlgs 286/1998 at article 6.3 that a foreigner must provide their passport for inspection to a police officer. Failing to do so, could lead to a 2000€ fine or a 1 year of prison.

Never took our passports when were were out and we started in The north of Italy right down to the south. We hid our passports in our room. Take pictures of your passport and use your drivers license as photo id. My phone was always in my possession or in my bag over the hubbys shoulder while he was taking a pic of me and I still could see my bag.

Regardless what the actual law is, I would weigh the pros and cons of carrying your passport.

Carry it with you or not?

1. What are the chances of being stopped by authorities asking to see your passport? Will a photo suffice?
2. What are the chances of your passport disappearing while locked in your hotel room?

3. What are the chances of your passport getting severely damaged, lost or stolen when taking it with you

4. Comfort level having your passport on you vs. left in a hotel safe or hidden in hour underwear stash

Always carry passports, leave a copy in luggage. Just saw a post where a couple had a room change while out sightseeing came back to hotel all baggage and safe contents moved to new room. Hotels have access to safes
Best to leave your passport, and one credit card, in hotel safe. If your handbag/wallet is stolen you will have your ID and at least one credit card. Learned this the hard way in Barcelona.

I’m a frequent traveler to Italy and I used to live there. I only ever carried my passport on me during COVID, when it was required, along with your vaccination card, to go anywhere (restaurants, shops, trains, etc). As many have suggested, take a picture of the photo page of your passport, keep it in your phone, and text it to a family member or friend back home - and leave the passport in the hotel safe or otherwise hidden.
Italian police can and may ask you to produce your passport at any time - happened to us in Venice last June.
Thieves don't look for passports, they want cash and expensive items

text: I know that a lot of people fly in and then rent a car. If you haven't experienced the high-speed trains of Europe you should try it. These aren't the trains of North America and Italy does it best. This wasआणखी our train from Paris to Milan on Frecciarossa. On the flats between the border and Milan it hit 295 Km/h. My husband was like a kid at a carnival and was hoping it would hit 300 ;) Since that was a long travel day (changed in Milan for Florence) we went First Class and it was more like a tour. We had roomy, comfortable seats, big windows, espresso and pastries. The scenery was varied and spectacular, ranging from the flat agricultural land of France, to terraced vineyards, to snow-capped mountains (and of course tunnels). It was the best travel day EVER.

text:
20-22 Oct: Rome (jet lag recovery on 20 Oct)

22-24 Oct: Cinque Terre

24-28 Oct: Florence / day trip to Pisa, Lucca

28 Oct-30 Nov: Venice

[away to another country]

10-12 Nov: Rome (only 1 full day is available)

Should I drop 1 city?
Assuming first and last day is usually allocated for travelling. Would appreciate suggestions.

TIA ☺️

comments.comment_text: Look up the melatonin regimen for dealing with jet lag. It’s really helped me.
I would drop Venice and do only Rome, Cinque Terre and Florence (without day trips). Consider that it will take some hours to travel between all places, if lucky without some delay 😅
Do Florence first and then Cinque Terre since it's closer to Rome.

I think the schedule is good. I would add one night in Rome. Do not skip Venice. I don't usually experience the jet lag going to another country, only when I return home. But what I find helpful is not to sleep at all the day I arrive, I just go and hit the ground running plus lots of coffee. 😃

We have a similar amount of time with our itinerary. We fly into Naples on September 17 (although leaving US on16th). We will spend one night, then take the train to Rome. Two nights in Rome, then train to Florence for two nights. After that it's back to Naples for four nights in Sant'Agnello (Sorrento area) and then two final nights in Naples. We've been booked since March and I've worked and reworked our time in each place numerous times trying to decide what gives us optimal time in each city. I've decided unless we had a month, there's no way to have enough time to see all we want to see. I keep second guessing myself, but I've decided to keep this schedule. I do wish I had arranged it so we could just stay in Florence for five nights and venture out from there, then spend the remaining time in Sorrento area. Rooms are now at a premium or nonexistent so it is what it is. Sigh.

text: Can someone vouch for how the atmosphere and food quality are at Antica Trattoria da Tito? I’m looking forward to it, but some reviews are scaring me a bit! 😅

comments.comment_text: What reviews?? I live in Florence. One of my favorite super local restaurant in Florence. Staff is always nice, food is great, prices are good considering the quality. I always go there with friends and family. I live in Florence. It's still a real local place. I usually have Fiorentina steak (not to be served with french fries EVER). It has a 4.6 review on trip advisor are you sure you are not checking the wrong place? There is a Tito restaurant in another area of Florence, Antica Trattoria Is in via San Gallo.

The atmosphere is real. Waiters and owner will get mad if you order a well cooked fiorentina steak. It's one of the few restaurants in Florence where tourists are not in charge so you will have to stick to their rules. Which is great because staff is the most rappresentative
of the Florentine culture you can get in Florence

text:
Lake Como & Lake District
After some advice please. Heading to Italy in july/august 24. We haven't been to the lakes area & wish to go. Lake Como is what we were thinking but after seeing the massive crowds this year, could anyone suggest an alternative? One of the other lakes or a lesser know town on Lake Como but still picturesque & accessible to sight seeing. Many thanks

comments.comment_text:
Lago di Como: Domaso in the north with ferry access to other places
Lago d'Orta
Lago Iseo
Lago di Garda: Salo
Lake Garda
Hotel Olivedo I. Varenna
Lake District is in the UK.
Lake como is around 160km long. There are so many beautiful places to explore. For some reason people are only interested in seeing bellagio. It’s lovely, but not the only place to see!
Go to Lago di Garda and there to the Westcost. Not crowded, not so expensive and so beautiful. I recommend Gargnano, Gardone Riviera and salo!
We just spent 4 days at Lake Garda and absolutely loved it.
Tremezzo
Lenno, and Menaggio both great towns on Lake Como. Less tourists than most of the others and beautiful towns. Both have ferry stops.
Lake Maggiore is absolutely beautiful. Stay is Stresa. Lovely little town
Lago Lugano. Já fica do lado suíço. E lindo e tem um passeio de barco lindo.

Come to Lake Ceresio (aka, Lago di Lugano)! I’m from Pittsburgh, but live in Valsolda, Italy, on Lake Lugano, about 4 km from the Swiss border. We are about 20 minutes from Menaggio, a popular tourist destination on Lake Como, so you could find an AirBnB in Valsolda (for less money and practically no crowds) and travel by bus or rental car to Lake Como and even visit the Swiss city of Lugano.
Lake maggiore is nice
We stayed in Lierna. Was a ten minute train ride to Varenna. Boat from there to Bellagio and the west side. Trains not busy.
We just got back from Lake Iseo. It was just gorgeous and very affordable.
Lake Maggiore (Stresa and Isole Borromee), lake Garda and La ke d’Orta.
Garda
Lake Garda. Malcesine or Limone. Not Riva or Sermione.

We stayed at Lake Lugano , was fantastic. We have also stayed on Lake Como at Varenna and that was wonderful and not busy .You can stay at other towns on Lake Como or even Lago Di Garda , Lago Maggiore
Can you still just turn up and buy a ticket at the villas on the lake at Como.
I agrée with Stressa on Maggiore. If you get a chance go to Lake Orta for lunch and a visit to the island.
We chose to go to Lake Lugano in Switzerland for this reason and loved it! Beautiful area with a small beach and you can rent a paddle boat. Food was delicious!
Another vote for Lake Maggiore! Base yourself in beautiful Stresa, so much to see and do. The Borromean Islands are a must visit via the local ferry. Do not miss the white peacocks on Isola Bella!
Lago Maggiore from Stresa to Ascona is hard to beat. The Ciento Valley is so close.
Vico lake. Is small and not crowed. Is near Roma, bolsena lake and bracciano lake.

We stayed in como in late may. Met a couple who stayed a much lesser known town and found the ferry schedule was not as frequent for their town which they felt was a mistake. Bellagio is the most crowded but best located for ferry schedules ( shorter rides etc). Como was less crowded and a bit of a lovely surprise w good ferry schedules but longer to to places like Varenna.
Going to stresa in lake maggiore. Beautiful and significantly less a night than lake como
I love Varenna. Last summer, we spent 4 nights in Varenna. You can ferry to other towns. There is a beach area, lots of restaurants, some shops, train station is nearby.

Just travelling back from a wonderful week in Lake Garda. We stayed in Riva del Garda and didn’t find it crowded at all and heaps to do. Visited limone, malcesine (both easily accessible by boat, bus and car) and Sirminone. All absolutely beautiful but sirmione v crowded but worth visiting we so different to the other towns.

We are here now at Villa Belvedere in Argegno and it is lovely! Went to Tremezzo yesterday for lunch at the Grand Hotel Tremezzo and ate on their patio and loved it! Argegno is small and very quiet. Tremezzo was busier but still wonderful. Stay away from Bellagio - it was a nightmare with crowds.
Lake Garda is bigger so the crowds may be more spread out. We stayed in Sirmione. Loved it. In Lake Como we stayed in Varenna

Lake Garda is still the best and from there you can go to Verona and to Brescia that is a NOT known city ( where i m from ) with a roman temple and domus and a fantastic castle!
And from garda lake you can move to all italy!
If your in that vicinity you should go see Bellagio!

I was there in June. It wasn’t like the recent photos in Italian papers but July and august are the most crowded.
Stay in Tremezzo on West Bank. You will be right next to villa Carlotta and villa Balbianello and can take the ferry to Bellagio to villa Melzi.

We loved Stressa on lake Maggiore. Much less crowded and palazzo Borromeo and palazzo Madre are the best.
Lago Maggiore / lago d'Orta (Amazing!)/ Lago d'Iseo/ Varese and its lakes and valleys..
Opting for Lake Garda you could stay in Verona. From there Venice is only an hour by train, also.

My kids always ask to go to Como. I still don't understand why.
We live ON Garda. It is bigger, beautiful and not nearly as crowded but still plenty of fun!

I would just pick another month.June or september.July and August all the lakes and cities and beaches will be overcrowded..it
s peak touristic season and Italians go on vacation en masse in August.I lived on Lake Garda and july and august is impossible.(esp
ecially august).

We just got back from Lake Como. Stayed in Moltrasio. It wasn’t crowded at all! Didn’t need reservations anywhere. The actual town of Como was a little crowded but we never waited for anything. Moltrasio was the perfect little town with a wonderful restaurant - La Baia. We loved it!! We easily caught the ferry to multiple towns over the course of three days.
Lake Maggiore is a beautiful area. I was there September in a beautiful hotel.
Garda and Iseo. Much better than Como
Love Malcesine on lake Garda and travel up mt Baldo on cable car for stunning mtn scenery. Also visit Limone and Riva del garda from there. Sirmione is wonderful too but a bit busier than Malcesine.

We enjoyed Malcesine in Lake Garda last year and spent a few days in beautiful Verona.

This week we have had a few days in Bergamo - hidden gem, a day trip to Brescia - both Italian cities of culture 2023 - tourists but in no way overcrowded. We’re now enjoying a week at Riva di Solto on Lake Iseo - much quieter than Garda and Como 😊

I love Bellagio. You can take a ferry around the lake and get off on any stop to sightsee. I’ve been twice and stayed once in Menaggio and once in Bellagio and loved Bellagio. I didn’t like the other lakes as much. Lake Como is the most beautiful place.

All the other lakes are less touristy and more authentic - and even on lake Como I know a lovely place - even with a little beach - where it´s great. just avoid the places that get mentioned frequently!
Try the hotel Villa Flori in Cernobbio on Lake Como, less crowded than other towns but nearby and beautiful

I’m from Como, I would suggest you to go on the Lecco side of the lake to avoid the crowds. Orrido di Bellano, Varenna, even Lecco are beautiful! Otherwise, I would recommend to visit some of the villas like Villa del Balbianello, Villa Carlotta or Villa Monastero, booking the ticket in advance on their website. They’re beautiful historical palaces and they have amazing views on the lake. Avoid the most touristic places like Bellagio! Unfortunately July and August are not the best months to visit Italy as Italians themselves have annual leave in those months 🥲

text: Looking to book the Vatican and Colloseum fast track tickets without the tour but most seem to just offer tours as well which we dont want to do. Anyone have any good sites that just offer entrance

comments.comment_text: Following
Get tickets from their official sites

Depending on when you are trying to go, to these sites.
The Vatican will open up the days, 2 months prior to your date, late afternoon in the US, 5pm (MST) and the Colosseum is 30 days at 9am local italian time, 2am (MST).
We booked through offical sites.

It's a real problem getting a simple entrance ticket to both places. The international OTAs buy everything up front and then resell, and upsell (guided tour, skip queue etc). The Rome authorities are aware of this. Opposite the Colosseum near the metro station is an official Rome tourist point. Ask them when you get there. And never buy or interact with hawkers offering tickets/help.
What is the official site for Vatican?

text:
Who has everyone used for planning (flights, hotels, trains, and excursions). I want a semi guided trip but also want some free time with my family tour guide free. Looking to start in Venice and work our way down, ending in Rome. Definitely want some coastal towns in the mix for beach days. Hoping this is about 10/11 days. I have seen many of these websites online but want to hear from people who have actually used them or a travel agent you used and loved.

***My mom will be 75 on this trip so planned transportation is a must

Thanks!!!

comments.comment_text: We are going to use Globus independent in September. It is a private tour with hotels, trains, half-day tours in each city, and English speaking host provided. Then the rest of the time is on our own. They only go to the main bigger cities.￼

Download TRIPIT as it gets linked to your email. Has all my flights, accommodations,
train rides, etc.

We plan and book everything ourselves directly with airlines, lodging and sites. We usually use Trainline to book train tickets. That way we are assured that lodging, transportation and activities are exactly what we want. If we want a guide, we just do a specific tour for a day or part of it. Regardless of planned transportation,
the old city centers are vehicle-free and cobblestone, so make sure that will work for your mom. Some places (like Rome) offer golf cart tours that will get her closer to sites without much walking.

Booked it all myself. Went last month. Decided to go 2 months prior. Everything worked out perfectly. And I’m not a natural born planner by any means.

Best tip: check addresses of places/things you want to do and book stays close by.

Also private drivers are the way to have a relaxing vacay.

Once we identified where we wanted to visit, we used a travel agent to help us find hotel reservations as well as the private tour times and places we wanted. He also gave us tons of recommendations
for things to do/visit in our down time. We found a TA really helpful in decreasing our stress!

We used our regular travel agent, She Plans Travel Co. Renee Cross, Travel Advisor. I gave her a list of areas/
things we wanted to see and do, and she planned our perfect custom itinerary. It included some small group tours, private tours, hotels, trains, private drivers, and recommendations for dining, additional things to do on our own, etc.
LuxTravel Katie
Following. Has anyone used tripmaster.com? This was recommended but never heard of it!
We used Costco. They are very flexible and organized flights, transfers, hotels, and trains between cities. All I had to do was book tours.
Patty's Life Without Regrets Travel. Would love to help!
Stay away from Expedia.

Do your research for hotels in Venice. Look for ones near an Alilaguna/
vaporetto stop with no bridges to cross or a hotel that has a window where a private water taxi from the airport can drop you right at your hotel.
I would highly recommend Nyssa from Click and Trip .
Booked it all myself.
We used AAA to plan our trip!
TripMasters!!

We booked through Costco, the travel agent was exceptional with helping us customize our trip. The included car service picks you up at airport as well as transfers you between locations.
I’d also recommend private tour guides, I’m trying to find the company we used, I believe they were students/or employed in art or history related fields. It was so much nicer to tour at our own pace and not struggle to hear in a larger group.

Christina Ricci-Campagnon
e

text: We will be in Italy next week. We will be driving through parts of Tuscany. What do you suggest we do with our bags? I’m terrified to leave them in the car(in the trunk not visible). I have 3 kids so carrying them all day isn’t an option. We will be in Orvieto, Pisa and Lucca. Is there secure parking? Do we store them somewhere? Leave someone with the car?

comments.comment_text: Skip Pisa
Janice Carbone 🚗

We ran into this in Costa Rica. We tried to never leave anything in the car, but sometimes it was unavoidable. What we did was when we'd leave one destination, we'd pack everything in the back (it was an SUV) and then use a bike lock to lock all of the stuff together and we latched that to the inside of the car. Make sure you have dark colored suitcases or a blanket if you end up with an SUV. When we got to where we were going, we never went near the back of the car or gave any indication there was stuff in the back.
From some posts on here I don't understand why anyone of a nervous disposition would visit Italy as it's made out to be sone crime ridden ghetto not the beautiful country that it is.

So for those suggesting a storage place, curious how that works? And how is that really safer than just leaving your stuff (obviously don’t rummage through it when you get out and make sure it’s covered, etc)? The stuff is being stored specifically where everyone knows you’re leaving it there…..how are items secured, guarded, etc at the storage places? I do a good bit of traveling, both abroad and domestic and I’ve really never felt like my belongings were more unsafe than right here in the US. 🤷🏼‍♀️
Pisa isn't worth it...skip it...gypsies are known to frequent there ...

Hey, pisa is skippable IMO, but to answer your question will you not be sleeping anywhere? Normally they let you leave your luggage in reception both before and after your check-in/check out. It sounds daft but the easiest option is to break up your belongings and hide them in separate parts of the car where not visible including under the car seats..you can also leave only clothes with a photocopy of your ID inside and bring your more valuable stuff on your person
We just drove on Tuscany this weekend. Left bags in trunk. Nothing visible. No problems.
Arriving in Pisa with luggage from train…isn’t there a storage unit there & can I get it without App?
They have alarms you can get for hotel doors I wonder if they could be rigged to cars or if they have portable alarms for cars? Worth checking out.
If you can look in vehicle and see any luggage don't leave car unattended
Do hire cars have alarms?
Pisa has luggage storage at the train station (I think 5 euro per bag for full day) and if you just have smaller bags I’d recommend StowYourBags near the train station as well (pay by the hour).
I got pickpocketed on a public bus to the Leaning Tower of Pisa. It can happen to you. They target tourists.

I wrote a post about Pisa in this group around the 12 July where I wrote a walking itinerary that takes you to the Tower through the nice area and not the roads where one-hour tourists pass and all the scammers are.
The itinerary starts from the railway station but just in front of the railway station there is an underground park in Piazza Vittorio Emanuele (not the cheapest park unfortunately) where I find very difficult to imagine robberies (in any case leave nothing visible!) Then you can walk twenty minutes and reach the Tower in all safety.
The problem is that everyone tries to see the tower in ten minutes and they all park really near it where all the scammer are: if you watch a map the Tower is not in the city center (where the river is) but it’s on a side (long story behind this position) just near a very cheap suburb.
The walking itinerary goes from Piazza Vittorio Emanuele to Keith Haring murales (fun for the kids), Corso Italia, you cross the river, Borgo Stretto, Piazza dei Cavalieri and the Tower (it’s 3/4 minutes longer than the shortest road but you will only walk in nice roads full of shops and things to see).

Myself I would always have a base and go off by train, as it’s not worth the risk for me and I go to Italy twice a year ,so far been very lucky haven’t been targeted as I for one blend in and my clothes are very Italian clothing, no caps, flip flops, young ones seem to wear what’s in fashion , most Italians wear linen ,cotton pants & shirts or t shirts, look at Pinterest that tells you a lot🌻
I wonder why someone found this funny? Store your luggage at a locker facility.
You’ll be fine in Orvieto and Lucca. Not sure about Pisa
Been once — it’s enough for a lifetime!!!

Italy in general isn’t safe especially Rome ! But Budapest and Prague weren’t better either. Creepy-looking people lurking everywhere after 6 pm. We were almost robbed in the public train while on our way to Vatican in B-road day light. Don’t trust Naples either — just too dangerous after 6 pm. I live in Europe and I don’t trust staying out after dark in Rome and for Eastern cities.

We have traveled a few times in a car for a month with suitcases and other goodies in the trunk. Here is what we have always done: after out of sight from the rental agency, removed all stickers on the exterior of the car; threw water and dirt on the car; tossed empty bottles, crinkled new papers, kids soccer balls or what ever toy or ball we could buy that was cheap in the car where it could be seen along with anything else we thought would like we were not worth robbing; and parked with our trunk firmly against a tree or wall.
My Italian boyfriend + I had all of our belongings stolen from his car in Pisa. They were in the locked trunk. Thank God we had our passports and valuables with us.

Just dont park where a tourist would park… spot a “business area” and blend in with all the cars of people who go to work. Have your belongings in the car trunk (maybe keep the valuables in a backpack always on you), and after parking the car do not even consider opening the trunk. Just pretend there’s nothing there and lock the car. Any bigger parking would have security cameras, so just don’t park it on the road.

You can Google for “Parcheggio sorvegliato” on Google maps. It’s parkings with guardians and cameras.

Leave the inside of the car a bit dirty and untidy (empty water bottle, maybe a sweatshirt, paper tissues).

No sense to park with your trunk against tree or wall, if they rob you they will break the glass, they usually don’t force the locks.

Most crime is opportunistic. Make it difficult. We brought a long cable bike lock. We lock our suitcases together when not with them. I always back into parking spots when possible that make it hard to open the trunk.
Look up online, luggage store sites.
I have downloaded an app for storing luggage ext, it's called Stasher
How about leaving your bags in a lift car in Pompeii? We won’t have the option to leave them at the train station as we are going onto Amalfi.
I felt unsafe in Pisa. The gypsies were bold!
Thanks for the heads up.
What is best fora cell phone in Italy, new SIM card in your smart phone or new cheap phone? From Canada
We just did all of those towns last week and didn’t have any problems at all.

Sadly the trunk is where pretty much everyone who would want to steal your bags will assume they are. Do your best to park somewhere where there is activity. Personally when I am in a similar position I will drop my family off somewhere so that when I park it is just me getting out of the car and I never open the trunk. Have never had an issue even in areas where I likely should have LOL. We had a van with a driver, in Pisa there were a lot of sketchy looking people milling about so we were glad to have a driver to stay with our bags.
You should be worried. If anything is visible from the outside while parked, your car becomes a prime target.
We stored out luggage in Lucca. If you get the Bounce app or the Stasher app you can look for luggage storage nearby.
Don't waste much time in Pisa.just 1 hour to look at the toner and leave.Siena is a must see.
As long as they are not visible, I think you’re fine. We haven’t had to leave ours but our trunk has never been broken into in the many times we have visited Italy.
Don’t worry about leaving bags in the car, especially if they can’t be seen. We do this all the time and never had an issue. Just make sure your car is locked.

I know this might sound silly, but as the former wife of a police officer, back into a parking space, if possible. If it’s dark, park by a street light. ￼Don’t leave things in the car that scream I am a tourist.
These places are quite safe you can stress less and leave in the car just avoid to leave high value objects inside
Leave them. It’s fine
Anonymous,I understand. Lately I have had men, "scammers" asking to be friends or making comments that I have no intention of answering.
Orvieto has parking near St Patrick's well, it's paid parking, in a busy area.
Download the app Bounce. Someone posted about it the other day. You can search to see if the towns have storage lockers. I searched Lucca and they do. Good luck.
Lauren Swanteck Myler
Look for a cover parking

It might come as a surprise but…

I’m Italian living in Italia, my family is 4 of us.
We do travel and have holidays in Italia, sounds weird I know but we do.
Never thought about our luggage in the car boot, apart for the normal common sense of not leaving things on sight, which I believe applies for every traveler in every country so…
Sorry but I don’t have any helpful suggestion

Question for the Italians in the group. Does anyone know if rental cars in Italy are easily identified as such - ie special plates, certain number series, etc.
This was once a problem in the US because anyone looking at the plate could tell it was a rental.
When we lived in Rome we heard about cars being broken into at some tourist locations, but it wasn’t clear if it was random or targeted in some way.
If a rental car can be identified in some way, then it would seem that the only option would be to store bags elsewhere because no amount of common sense precautions would help.

You have to do what you have to do. Lucca and Orvieto should be okay. Just to go paid parking lot and you really should be fine. I would put an AirTag in the luggages and try not to get anything out of the trunk when you park so no one sees that you have your luggages in there. Have fun. I love all the places but Orivieto to Pisa is a good 3 hours drive. Where are you staying? Maybe consider staying in Orvieto for a couple of nights and Lucca for another 2?

Be VERY cautious in Pisa. Not worth taking the time to visit compared to other areas. Only place we felt unsafe was by the Tower. A gang (gypsy type) surrounded us & wanted my husbands watch & our iPhones. It was terrifying for our children. Very gritty & sketchy IMO first hand opinion. I would just skip Pisa
I dont blame people posting anonymously, probably because of all the 'Karens' who give such nasty replies.

in each of those towns, check to see if the train stations have luggage storage. But even if they do, pack in such a way that any important docs always stay with you such as passports, prescriptions, a few days of meds, electronics, etc. Suitcases should be safe in the trunk but be careful not to be seen rummaging through suitcases in trunk in public. (It's the same advice to never count your money in public). Should they be stolen, it's only clothes. An additional piece of equipment to consider (out of paranoia) is to get a piece of aircraft cable with loops at each end, maybe 6' and a padlock. Easily rolled up and carried in a suitcase. Most trunks will have some sort of metal loop attached to the frame. Run the cable through the suitcase handles and padlock to the inside of the trunk. We have done this on trains where we can't monitor our luggage at the end of the car: we just loop them together. One more little defense. But overall, crime is less prevalent in italy than in the U.S. Relax, breathe.

I was in Orvieto a few weeks ago and where I parked seemed like the main place to do so. It was multiple stories with the lower levels rather dimly lit, it’s then a series of stairs/
elevators/
escalators to get up into the actual town, so the garage is a bit isolated. That said, I parked on the lowest, worst lit floor and had belongings out of sight in the trunk overnight and everything was fine. I wouldn’t leave anything of tremendous value, but I’d have no worries doing it again.

text:
Someone posted that even though they had on a money belt, their valuables were stolen and they lost everything. That's just awful!

So, what are you using/wearing to ensure your valuables are safe, both men and women? I purchased two banana sling type purses with zippers on the back side, but they are not anti-slash. Money belts look bulky for my husband, but if we can find one that's less bulky, he can get one.

Ideas? Tips? Suggestions?

Thanks!

comments.comment_text: I wore a small crossbody that held a few cards, my phone and a lip color. I wore a shirt and mid skirt combo and when I’m crowds, I slipped my purse into the waistband and under my skirt. Worked perfectly!
I was very scared about this problem. I have not had any problems in Florence just be careful like you would be any city
I plan on bringing very little while I am out. Leave my valuables in the hotel

Here almost a week all over Rome. Traveled to Naples 1/2 day and been to Positano as well.

I have a cross body small bag but haven’t used it once. Just keep wallet in front pocket with a backpack for water, cooling towels etc. i was nervous for me and kids reading this site but it’s been fine. Just have your wits about you and be safe.

So sad but it happens. I always roll my eyes when people think it’s stupid when people ask about it. I have Italian family and friends in Florence and they are very well aware of this happening. The thieves almost always target tourists but do go after citizens sometimes.

I wear an under the shirt money belt for my passport and credit cards when in certain areas. Like up around my bra band. In a small purse I carry a small amount of cash and hand sanitizer.

Just be aware in busy areas, don’t stare at your phone. If you have to look something up stand with your back against a wall.

My backpack has a small pocket with zipper on the side of my back. Never had problems

Just don't act too suspicious and don't carry a lot of Wörth with you

Had a younger friend in his 40s boo hoo my suggestions when he went to Italy. He lost literally everything including his luggage in less than 5 mins after he arrived to Italy and left the airport. EVERYTHING! He was too embarrassed to tell me how it happened. He's a good looking guy so I suspect the pickpocket person was an attractive woman. He still won't tell me what happened months later.

Safety pin the bags to your body. That way if the strap is slashed the purse is still attached. Also, pin the zipper to the bag, so it can’t be easily opened. Split up your valuables. Put some money and a credit card in different zipper compartments

Just beware. If you are on subway and someone causes a disturbance be extra cautious of belongings. Thats when they hit . They cause a commotion and you are looking around. I was a victim on the subway in Rome.

I wore a small pack, mostly on my back, I would shift to my front when we were in crowded places. My gf looked out for me, I tried to do same for her. We weren't overly paranoid, just conscience and cautious. Common sense goes a long way. The biggest issue we experienced, I left my beloved water bottle on the train lol.
I had friends there last week in an Airbnb. The thieves came through the window, while they were sleeping. Took passports, money & jewelry. It’s no joke.
Don’t carry a lot of cash
My husband bought the safe from pick pocket pants. They are on Amazon, the brand is Rhone. Very comfortable as well

If the crossbody, anti-theft bag is visible, you are a target. Locals don’t use them. If you use a “Rick Steves” type money belt for your pp, large $$ and extra credit cards, UNDER your clothes, that is probably safe. I do carry a bag with “comforts”. But I know that it and the contents could be lost, stolen or forgotten at any time. I don’t but put any valuables there. Be aware of your travel group, (don’t let anyone fall behind alone) and your surroundings as you would in any large city, on any day of week.
I didn’t realise it was such an issue. I am from uk and have been to Italy umpteen times & have never had any problems
Robert Rodriguez
I have shorts with zip pockets. The zips are quite difficult to open. You don’t need wads of cash - almost everybody takes contactless credit cards.

I used my Lululemon belt bag all through Italy earlier this summer and had no issues. Just kept it in front of me and was aware of my surroundings. My husband and sons all used money belts under their clothes, and even my less attentive son was fine.

Usually I travel in winter so I got jacket and long sleeve hoodie covering my watch,I put my passport in my inner jacket pocket

For other valuables I wear money belt inside my thermal undies

Depending on the place I’m visiting,I wear anything from big waterproof equipment backpack to Hermes slingbag (filled only with pocket umbrella,sungla
sses,scarf etc)
I left my phone with all my cards and ID at a restaurant in Sicily and when I went back they had it in the safe for me.

Ok don’t call me crazy. I have a messenger bag that zips. I put a carbine/latch to lock it. Then I have a rfid zippered pouch for my cards/money that I put inside another zippered pocket inside. It is attached to the zipper through an O ring. So 3 zippers and the wallet is attached. Even if they cut the side or bottom, the zippered compartment is not attached to the side. I tether my phone to my purse as well. I then keep half my stuff in another place but that is also tied to the inside of my purse. Nothing is absolute but there is no quick taking anything out of my purse. Hopefully they will see how hard it is for me to get in it and stay away 😂. And I keep it in front of me so there is a double thick canvas strap in the back.

I use travelon that has slash proof, but I’ve also never had anyone try cut my purse off of me, so I feel like what you have will probably be ok. The main thing is to pay attention to yourself, your belongings and your surroundings.

https://
www.amazon.com/
gp/aw/d/
B06XBKN584?psc=1
&ref=ppx_pop_mo
b_b_asin_title I use this anti theft purse! Cost is good and it’s decently cute 😊

I have a backpack with a clip up flap that goes over the zip and then put a carabiner through the zip tabs so they are locked together. I also wear the backpack on my front in crowds. If they can get into that, good luck.

So curious - traveling to Italy for the first time in Sept. where do you keep your passports when traveling? I felt like it was better to have with us in a protected crossbody but now I’m wondering if we should leave it in our hotel. But I don’t love that idea either. Thanks for any info

I am a woman and I always travel alone. I’ve been to the Amazon, places in South America and the Caribbean, Manhattan, Paris, Italy, Barcelona, Dublin, etc. I’ve never been robbed.
Frankly, I try not to look like I’d be worth robbing. No expensive clothes or jewelry. One small pouch around my neck that I can put down my shirt. It only carries passport, some euros, one credit card and lipgloss.
I also am very aware of my surroundings (aren’t most women who are alone?) and if I need my resting bitchface, I’ll put it on.
I know it could happen to me but I see what some other tourists look like and frankly, if I were shady, I would salivate at the easy pickins’. I mean no offense and as a woman who has worked with many victims of violence, I am adverse to victim blaming, but some people just ooze vulnerability.
That being said, while I haven’t been robbed, “there but for the grace…”.

Honestly, I had a thin profile money belt hidden inside the waist of my shorts. My wife carried a very small Crossbody bag always in front of her. We didn’t encounter any issues. ￼ we never felt like we had to actually protect ourselves except proactively on the metro.
￼
How do you keep your phone safe?
Pick pockets are actually well dressed and look more affluent. Often young women. Will be carrying something to use to conceal - like an umbrella or jacket.

Baggallini womens Securtex®... https://
www.amazon.com/
dp/
B07WS33SHQ?ref=p
px_pop_mob_ap_s
hare
Pickpocket proof pants. My husband loves his. They have shorts too

I wear the money belt, for my husband and I, with passports and emergency cash. I always keep it under my clothes. I’ve seen people who wear money belts over their clothes or across their body, I wouldn’t do that. The money belts are hot and uncomfortable, but after awhile, I don’t think about it.
That’s crazy
Susan Miller Rubin Santandreu what was your experience ? These pickpocket stories are plentiful

The best advice to to pay attention to your surroundings. Not look lost, confused, looking up. I use a crossbody purse with pockets, zippers. I don’t intend to change that. I have that Lululemon belt and would not be using that. If it turns, someone could easily get in it, same if you wear it across you. I’m certainly not wearing it under my clothes.
I wear a cut proof cross shoulder bag. When we are in busy areas my husband walks behind me.
Slash proof is good, for sure. Crossbody. And pay attention, always.
Contrary to popular belief, most people don’t get pickpocketed.
Slash proof crossbody and RFID blocking clip stash pouch

Look confident, don’t wander around dubious areas, use your gut instinct. Money belts should be hidden from sight. Spread your money around your body. Never, ever put your wallet or purse in your back pocket. Don’t brandish your money openly. Be aware of your surroundings.

I’ve had friends personally be victimized by pick pocket. The best advice they said, after they got their stuff back was, be aware of your surroundings. They work in pairs. One person to distract you, the other to get the goods. If you have anything that zips, keep that in front of you and with you hand on the zipper. These types of transactions had only happened in close quarters on the train, that was it. I live in Italy and have had no issues, been here since March. Tight, close quarters is where it will happen. They won’t hurt you, they just want your stuff. Don’t be afraid to travel or explore Italy. She’s beautiful, there’s so much history and beauty.

People that were walking right in front of us on the Spanish Steps were attacked by 5 girls, they went through his zipper pocket pants and her cross body bag less than 4 seconds
My husband tried getting the girls off of him, but they new what they were doing, they were probably 14 years of age
It was horrible
There was no way of stopping them
They came and left within seconds
Just avoid to have all together and have a big amount of money. Go to atm and take what you need

I wear clothing arts pick pocket proof shirts and pants. Expensive but worth it. Plus I try to avoid crowds when I can and always walk with an air of authority even though I’m faking it at times! No problems in Rome, Paris or NYC

Don’t look like a tourist. Leave the expensive jewelry and clothes at home. Avoid clothes and accessories with labels.
Stay alert.
I have a Travelon slash-proof crossbody with zippers that clasp shut. I wear it in front all the time. Amazon has a great selection of different styles and sizes.

Was the money belt under their clothing? The main thing is to not carry all your valuables in one spot. Some women will wear a bra stash to hold some cards and cash and then carry a small amount in a cross body bag. I’ll post photos of some things as comments below this post.

text: Folks, are there luggage lockers in Rome & Naples train stations? I am asking this coz we will be checking out of the hotel early in Naples to do a full day Pompeii tour and heading to Rome that evening...meanwhile wondering what to do with luggage...thanks for all your help!

comments.comment_text: Your hotel should not have an issue stowing your luggage there for the day, usually.
Check out bounce. They have storage near stations in many cities.
Yes! We stored our luggage right at the Naples train station. It’s on the main floor and I want to say it was 24 euros for 4 pieces of luggage for 3 hours.
Yes.Also check out the Bounce app
Yeah they are everywhere just Google luggage storage near where you want to be
You can pay to store them in Napoli train station.. there’s a place inside .. also there’s a luggage drop off on a side street near the train station
Ask at the hotel can you leave your luggage, my hotel in Rome allows me to leave it for weeks at a time🌻
Pompeii has free luggage storage
Make sure make a reservation for them before you arrive
Check them at the hotel where you're staying and pick them up later
Stasher.com will help you find luggage storage

text: We would like to spend a couple of months in Sicily in February - April timeframe. Yes, we know the weather can be a bit cooler. We would like a place in a town, preferably seaside, where we can walk and immerse ourselves. Any suggestions on towns and places (Airbnb/vrbo/hotel)? Thanks!

ing smaller seaside town to stay at.We got to see it on a daytrip on our last visit to Italy.Close to Palermo which is the capital only an hour away by train.Cefalu has a Norman Arabic cathedral which is considered a UNESCO heritage site.Worth a visit.Cefalu is also close to other towns to visit as well.

text: I’ve heard that Naples is a very unsafe area and I was really excited to go there. Can anyone share experiences in that area?

comments.comment_text:
Went yesterday from Rome. It has its own charm. Never felt unsafe. We walked through one neighborhood recommended. Nice with charm. Wakes over to path along water then stopped for pizza at L’Antica Da Michelle.

Overall good but 1/2 day was fine for us.

Many large cities are smelly, dirty etc, NYC included where I’m from. I felt more safe here.
I would go to Italy before America 😝
Naples is perfect. Stay in Centro area
we stayed near the historical center and it was really vibrant and nice. Best pizza ever and the people were really friendly and accommodating. We loved Napoli.
Stay home

Napoli é bellissima.My favourite Italian city..ancient,i
nteresting,hist
orical, beautiful.We have been 3 times and stsyed in the historical centre along Via dei Tribunali.Like every city anywhere,you have to be mindful of your surroundings.

most young Arab men. I enjoy walking the neighborhoods and not the tourist areas. Did not feel safe at all exploring the area. Luckily I just Naples just to spend nights there. Did day trips to Positano, Sorrento, Capri, Mt Vesuvius etc.

I spent January in Naples (most of it alone). It is a VERY bustling city, but has lower crime rates than Milan and Rome. We loved it so much we are considering purchasing our retirement home there. I ventured to Naples on my own for a few days as hubby couldn’t get the time off. Absolutely fabulous few days. The culture, the food, the architecture, the narrow streets with motorbikes whizzing up n down with mum, dad and their children on them…. Two days ago outside our hotel

I loved it, never felt unsafe. The food is amazing, the people are friendly and it has so much character. (For context im from Australia where it's really safe.)

Enjoy ! Pizza is great ;)

Just a big busy city

No true
I was unsafe 30 years ago

I’ve just spent 3 days there alone as a young female traveller (Pompeii prior to that). I walked from the train station, wandered amongst the back streets to my hotel, went to the sights in the centre, ate alone on an evening and then took a local bus across town to another local hotel near the airport…
Naples had a very different feel to Tuscany/ Rome/ Pompeii/ amalfi etc… all the places I’ve been before. For me, it felt a little daunting in comparison just because it’s so busy but I honestly didn’t feel unsafe. The people on the local bus helped me out with where to stop, staff helped me in restaurants and at the metro stations, locals said hi when I walked past, I asked for directions etc and everyone I came across was so helpful. I speak a little Italian which helped and I think was appreciated. Would happily go back. Honestly go places with an open mind, do some research and enjoy yourself! One persons like is another’s dislike….
It’s not any different than any other city

Lots of it, like anywhere, is being aware of surroundings, not looking for trouble and having purpose. Realize there are times people do everything right and bad things happen but I wouldn’t give Naples a bad rap

Naples is real, amazing food, less touristy. I suppose you can call it gritty but once you look past it it’s amazing. The history and the culture is incredible. Watching people drive and being in traffic was an amazing cultural experience. You get to see true local people living in their busy city.
There is lots to do in Naples and it’s a great base to see Capri, Amalfi Coast, Pompeii and Vesuvius.

We stayed in the Chiaia district close to the Castel dell'Ovo.
It was magical to see the sea, the ships coming and going, the sunset. Families leisurely walking enjoying their evening.
I say anyone should experience it for themselves
So it’s a big city. Comparable to nyc maybe. It’s got the good and the bad. I was actually attacked by a homeless man there last year but something about the city is special still
Never had a problem
I have zero desire to visit. So many other places to go to
We stayed in Il Convento right in the Spanish Quarter for 3 nights. Never felt unsafe. Loved Naples. Do some research of course to find what you’d like to visit
Great museums, food and people. Itlike any big city. Keep your valuables close and don't let them out of your sight. Same advice for any large city anywhere, including the US.
It is wonderful.
Following

September last year. Stayed in an AirbnB. Did a guruwalk through the Spanish Quarters with a great guide who totally enlightened me about Napoli, historically and socially.
The guided walk changed everything for me.
We visited the Archaeological Museum which is fantastic! It has the best stuff from Pompeii.
We loved the food, lots of great street food apart from pizza. Fabulous seeing our neighbours buying from street vendors and having produce delivered to second floor balcony via a bucket on a rope.
I felt safe at all times.
The Neapolitans are known for their exuberance, sentimentality,
music, and humour. The most famous Italian comedian was Toto, and there is a street dedicated to him in the Spanish Quarters.
Do yourself a favour and do a guided tour, it will help you understand why Maradona is seen as such a hero.

We stayed in the Centro Storico (old town ) area and didn’t feel unsafe at all. Naples is heaving with people, so suggest you keep your purse close as you would in any crowded area. We loved our time there.
I had heard that also prior to us visiting. I never felt unsafe while we were there ( day trip) it is kind of gritty and dark but seemed ok
I stayed in Naples in the centro historico district for 3 nights.. I never felt unsafe!

It’s a big city with nice and not so nice bits.
Like any city the ports and stations are where it’s most ‘hairy’.
We were fine wandering about lost, but we are used to big cities…

We based ourselves in Naples in 2019 for 9nights and never felt unsafe, just be mindful of your belongings, particularly down by the train station area. We stayed in a lovely b+b, “Hermes rooms for tourists” and the owners were so friendly and helped us plan our trips - Pompeii, Herculaneum, sorrento/
amalfi, ischia 😊

We were there 2 days ago, we were cautious after reading various comments. First impressions outside Napoli Centrale weren’t great but the further away from there we go the nicer it was. We enjoyed our time but it’s like anywhere really, be mindful of your surroundings and you’ll be fine

So Napoli gets a bad rep, but it’s really turned itself around.

You need to watch out at the train station - but that’s at every train station. (Pick pocketers)

Infact all I keep hearing about down here is how unsafe Rome is becoming. (& Milano has the most crime per capita at the moment)

I went to Naples twice in the last month and it’s the safest I felt there, ever.

It's more common sense like anywhere when travelling watch your stuff don't leave your wallet out and you should be fine.
I stayed in the Chiaia neighborhood. Very nice area, and only a couple of metro stops to the center.

text:
Hello! How long does it take to get through Naples Airport? We are travelling to Naples in August and wanting to explore Naples for a couple of hours before heading to Sorrento.
Our flight arrives Naples at 10:40 AM and was wondering if we have enough time to eat pizza and catch a 2:20 PM train to Sorrento?

comments.comment_text: Are you travelling on a flight from within the Schengen Zone or outside (ie UK or US). If it's the latter depends on how fast passport patrol is, can sometimes take a long time if a lot of flights from the UK arrive at the same time. I would just buy the ticket on arrival in case of any unexpected delay or cancellation.
See what great pizza places are within easy walk or cab from the central station and just make sure you leave time to get back and catch the train. if flight is late, just bad luck.

text: Does anyone know a Beach Club in Amalfi Positano or Sorrento that will take online bookings to reserve beach chairs looking to go in a few weeks and don’t want to wing it when I get there. Thanks guys!!!

Natalie Sydes, Glenn Malisauskas, beach club day??

text:
I’m going to Rome at the end of September going into October…we are going to rent a car and drive either to Florence or Naples. We are trying to decide which one?

Also, we are wanting a self guided tour to the Vatican and colosseum. Where did you all buy your tickets from and should we consider doing a guided tour?

I appreciate any suggestions!

comments.comment_text: FLORENCE FOR SURE!

Yes Florence is preferable though gets very busy and the Amalfi coast if you have time. Don't bother with a car as parking is difficult in these areas. Would also recommend Venice and the lake regions of Italy.
Pre-book skip the queue tours for the Vatican and Colliseum in Rome. Have fun!
Viator

Florence instead of Naples for sure!! Yes take a guided tour. There is so much history and you will not understand it all without a guide!
Florence absolutely. Skip Naples. It’s a bit gritty.

Firenze is a must! I had an apartment in Firenze for 3 months, made it my base, caught buses, trains etc.
Naples is great, but it’s really the Amalfi coast that is magnificent. Sorento, Positano is amazing.
Go to your local travel agent, pick their brains, and google how you find a guided tour.
Have an amazing time! Italy will change your lives , architecture, history, culture, food and the people!
Get lost!!! You will discover amazing places! And look up when you are walking, so you get your bearings! I used to love getting lost. Be mindful of the Gypsies! They are the only down side, especially in Rome at the train station!
Have a wonderful adventure! 🙏

Buy an Italian/
English dictionary, and strongly advise going to your local Dante Allergie to learn the basics!
You can stop off on way to Sorrento in Naples - I loved Naples - just the Italy I wanted to see - amazing food, shopping much cheaper than northern cities, gorgeous sights
Federico Pelegrino tour guide phenomenal & will not disappoint. He was born in Rome. We had a private tour & dinner in the gardens at the Vatican.
Take the train instead Fantastic Italia Trains
Florence is great for artistic culture…Naples and south are great for lifestyle culture…
Would not recommend driving around Florence. Best to take a train and walk the city.

Parking
Always The consideration
When renting a car
Vs using the trains
Which
Are really great in Italy
Viator
Guided tour because you gain entry faster and you won't waste time getting lost in the Vatican. They cover the high points and you can wander after if you feel like it.

Naples 10 years ago was amazing and the food is fantastic. Easy boat ride over to Capri that was phenomenal and food unbeatable.
We did a private boat ride around the island and saw Sophia Lauren’s house.

text: We will be in Rome Sept. 4-6 and I regret not buying our tickets yet!! What sites would you recommend booking a tour for, and what sites can we just buy a skip-the-line ticket for (if needed at all). The Vatican is already sold out so I will have to purchase a ticket/tour from an agency. Any other Rome tips welcome as well, as it's our first time!

comments.comment_text: Do not use crown tours! They scammed us over 600 dollars.
Do Skip the line on Get your Guide or Viator

Just relax and enjoy the city. So much to do. Take a Metro to see the great basilicas. The art and the buildings are so amazing. Walk the streets, sit and drink coffee or Prosecco and people watch. See great monuments as Romans do: as part of fabulous streetscapes, go to less tourist visited areas like EUR, the monumental buildings there that Mussolini had built to try to rival Ancient Rome, walk in the parks on the Appian Way and elsewhere, eat great food,. The list could go on for pages.

You will need tickets to get in the Borghese Gallery, gorgeous sculptures. I think you have to pay $5 to get into The Pantheon, but hopefully you can still show up and walk in after paying. Golf cart tours?
Agency and tour companies don’t have extra tickets. If it’s sold out, it’s sold out. As an advisor, don’t fall for buying from someone that could likely cancel on you.
Use Travelocity

Tickets for the Colusseum for your dates have not even gone in sale yet! They appear 30 days in advance, so get familiar with the website coopculture.it now. They will sell out or be limited to some times of the days, but you can still do it!!
We went on a street food tour. We had amazing food and learned a lot about the city.
Buy your tickets 🎫 it will make your life easier. Take a Vatican tour well worth it.

Get your guide or viator! Hopefully you are able to get into the Vatican. I booked 2 months in advance as that’s the earliest you can do. I know many people don’t realize how fast they go especially now with everyone traveling. If not you will have to come back again one day! This was my 2nd trip and only went to the Vatican as last time it was closed last time. It’s fun walking around and seeing all the other sites.
Can you get book the Galleria Borghese?
Do a tour. Try Airbnb Experiences and Viator for city tours and others to places of interest

text:
Question about car rental and ZTL, sorry if it’s been asked before but I couldn’t find the answer when using search tab..
we’re returning our rental in Florence and the drop off site looks to be in city center. How can I avoid ZTL zone if I need to go in the city center to drop the car off.
Thank you in advance.

comments.comment_text: Usually customers get, when returning the car (or arriving at hotels) a temporary permit “ex post”. The employee or concierge communicates the plate number to the local police and they will issue the permit and withdraw the fine. Better check with the rental company
Put the address in your g p s And it will take you directly there on the correct road
The ZTL zone is only some streets in the centre. Google maps will direct you around those streets.

The car rental company puts your license plate into the system so you don't get a ticket. We rented from hertz for 2 legs of our trip and this is how they explained it to us. Additionally if your hotel is in the ztl zone the hotel puts your license plate into the system. Our hotel in florence was in the ztl zone. My husband dropped us off before returning the car. I told the hotel Manger as we were checking in and he just asked for our plate number.

HOTEL DON FERRANTE 5* - PUGLIA
A romantic and charming getaway for two
Don Ferrante is a charming house in Monopoli Old Town, an ancient fortress on the reef, close to the sea, in an enchanting atmosphere.From… आणखी the moment you wake up, the sea breeze will follow you for the whole day, whilst the calm sea will be your soundtrack as you fall asleep.This stunning boutique hotel only has 10 rooms, meaning that this is the perfect place to seek peace and romantic moments.
